Award.AwardTitle: Long Term Population Response to Environmental Fluctuation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
As evidenced in many regions of the world today environmental change can have major impact on population distribution as groups of people may migrate in mass, disperse more broadly over the landscape or congregate in adaptive response. Archaeology, hand in hand with paleoclimate sciences, provides an excellent context within which to evaluate this process because it permits the reconstruction of both long term environmental fluctuation and human response. Such changes can play out slowly over multiple centuries and vary across multiple states. In this research project Drs. Douglas Kennett and Thomas Harper of Pennsylvania State University will focus on one such case dating to the Early Bronze Age period in Eastern Europe. During this period of climatic unstability settlement patterns indicate a highly volatile variation in population dynamics. During one time interval dispersed populations merged into "giant-settlements" which attained sizes of 100-320 hectares unique not only in size but also in the fact that they show no sign of internal social stratification. While these settlements, have been the focus of prior study, they are poorly dated and thus it is difficult to situate them tightly in an environmental context which is chronologically controlled. Researchers will collect relevant cultural material for radiocarbon dating to construct a cultural sequence which is tightly anchored in time.

In order to firmly establish the habitational sequence, the researchers will obtain datable materials (faunal bone samples; though a contingency using charcoal may be implemented in some cases) from a selection of twenty-two undated or poorly dated sites with artifact assemblages suggesting occupation ca. 4200-3300 BC. These sites represent the periods on either side of the giant-settlement phenomenon, Materials from these sites are kept in the collections of the Institute of Archaeology of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine (Kiev), the Museum of Tripolye Culture and other regional museums and archaeological authorities. Co-PI Harper will travel to Ukraine for the month in order to perform relevant collections research. Samples will be packed and shipped to Penn State where they will be cleaned, prepared and radiocarbon dated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project, conducted in cooperation with the Institute of Archaeology of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine (IANASU), we produced 68 accelerated mass spectrometry (AMS) radiocarbon dates from 25 archaeological sites dating to the Late Eneolithic period (ca. 4200–3000 BC) in Central Ukraine. These dates make a substantial impact on the absolute chronology of Eastern European prehistory during the fifth and fourth millennia BC, contributing high-resolution dating methods to a region where they have been as-yet poorly utilized. While several international archaeological projects are ongoing in Ukraine, ours is unique in its emphasis on larger-scale phenomena, seeking to understand broader patterns of human settlement and culture change over a long duration of time. Our campaign of radiocarbon dating allows us to substantially address a host of topics that have been queried over the course of decades of archaeological investigations. These topics include: the initial colonization of the forest-steppe region by agricultural communities, the probable relationship between population movements and changing climate in the region during the Middle Holocene, cross-cultural contacts at the frontier with the Eurasian steppe, and socio-economic transformations in the centuries leading up to the Early Bronze Age.

 

The Eneolithic in Central and Western Ukraine is largely synonymous with the Tripolye culture, which is famous for its “giant-settlement” or “megasite” phenomenon, where large settlements of 100–320 hectares (and thousands of inhabitants) emerged during a roughly 500-year period in the forest-steppe region. We sought to understand the broader cultural and environmental context of these large population movements, by testing the presumed chronological sequence of sites and archaeological materials, both large and small. Our results have substantial impact on our understanding of the regional chronology, in some cases confirming traditional hypotheses and in other cases revising the sequence or pace of different archaeological phenomena. Radiocarbon dates reveal that several sub-phases belonging to the middle part of the Tripolye culture are in fact poorly differentiated in Central Ukraine and, while not wholly synchronous with one another, represent far more truncated timespans than previously assumed. While very small farming communities existed in this region since the beginning of the Neolithic, our data suggest that widespread colonization of the region by populations of the Middle Tripolye culture occurred rapidly, beginning in approximately 4150 BC. Our dating of the sequence of sites belonging to the Eastern Tripolye Culture in the Southern Bug and Middle Dnieper regions is novel, and these dates may now be compared directly with the far better-studied Tripolye giant-settlements. In most cases, our results dating to the time span of 4000-3600 BC confirm the chronologies proposed by Ukrainian specialists in material typology, who have built chronologies based on pottery seriation. Our project has produced the first dates from the major site of Kosenovka, which show that it is a century or more older than previously assumed. While it is not a giant-settlement itself, cross-dating based on materials from Kosenovka allows us to more accurately estimate the end of the giant-settlement phenomenon, which substantially pre-dates the beginnings of the transition to the Early Bronze Age.

 

On the broader level, our data help us in examining cultural links with the Eurasian steppe, a region with a very different, more mobile way of life from the Eastern European forest-steppe. This was accomplished by dating burials of the Dnieper-Donets cultural complex that contained grave goods sourced from the Tripolye culture. These dates allow us to more accurately synchronize the evolution of these archaeological cultures and contextualize cross-cultural interaction between sedentary and mobile populations on the steppe frontier. Finally, the acquisition of several dates at the interface with the Early Bronze Age helps us in addressing the long-standing question of the nature of the transition between the Eneolithic and Bronze Age, which mostly appears in the archaeological record as a discontinuity in technology and cultural practices. We continue our support for the hypothesis that regional Eneolithic cultures were rapidly supplanted by the Yamnaya horizon not long after 3000 BC, and that there was not a protracted period of coexistence between Eneolithic and Early Bronze Age peoples.

 

To date, our activities have directly resulted in the preparation of five papers in journals and edited volumes, while more are being planned. Publication of results will likely continue for some time and our collaborative research efforts with IANASU continue to have an impact on our collective understanding of the regional archaeological record.
